page.title: 02BLACKMORE VALE LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Little mention of this area is found in Domesday.Later it was part of the Royal Hunting Forest of Gillingham and being crossed by many brooks was boggy -hence BLACKMOOR.The land was slowly cleared and settled but still today is thinly populated. The lowering of the level of the R.Stour in 1939 by 1m has improved drainage and lessened risk of floods.Except where an angling club has fishing rights the brooks are badly choked by weeds and dead trees Many public footpaths cross the area leading to footbridges over the streams but they are little used nowadays and difficult to follow. Communication by hard-surfaced roads is fairly adequate in this area but isolated farms are a mile from a made up road and need their own transport Farmers use modern methods are hard- working and make a comfortable living.
